message: Greetings, Ruby-ists (and maybe @mojombo), I was curious about the status of the God project/gem. The last commit was Sept. 2010, and there are a few outstanding pull requests in GitHub.
Also I'm curious about how it's doing on Ruby 1.9, if anyone has any experience. I see some posts and issues that try to answer some questions.

God is quite stable in its current release, but I do intend to sit down and review the existing pull requests soon. I also intend to release a 1.0 this year and put out comprehensive docs. We use God for all our production process monitoring at GitHub.
May God be present and start on all our servers... Actually, its funny I was checking some god config files and starting it, when I saw this pop on my email client...
Awesome, thanks @mojombo. Glad to hear it's doing well; in my extremely limited experience, I like it better than Monit.
@Cicloid Hehe, actually it was interesting, I work for a faith-based university, so when "Configure God" showed up in the Basecamp to-dos, I had to do a little bit of clarifying. :)
may be changing the name to godhctaw would help... ;-) just kidding
@itsnotvalid I'm embarrassed at how long it took me to get that.
@BinaryMuse I thought that was the reason why this tool has the name after a word in English with such meaning...

@BinaryMuse I'm using it with 1.9 for http://hackerbooks.com, I only saw one bug: the directory option does not apparently work (I used rake -f path/to/Rakefile as a work-around). Apart from that I'm happy with it!
Sort of off-topic, but is there much competition with people using BluePill(https://github.com/arya/bluepill), since their motivation seemed based solely on long-running God processes leaking memory?
@klauern, Bluepill is a Ruby app too, so it might leak memory just like God. I use Monit because it's written in C and is fast as hell.
The language has nothing to do with memory leaks. In fact being written and C if you don't manage memory by yourself you could end up with worse problems than memory leaks.
@inkel, of course. Monit manages memory. Anyway, interpreted languages are slower (apart from node.js)
in languages with garbage collection, there is still memory management
...and Monit does a good job of managing memory, by most accounts
@BinaryMuse LOOOLLL xD
God no longer leaks memory. That is a thing of the past.
@mojombo, great. Now how much memory and CPU does it use?
@myfreeweb Our production god instances at GitHub stabilize around 60MB RSS and 0.3% CPU on Debian boxes.
@BinaryMuse I suppose that actually was hilarious
